utterances: Well, what do you mean by our side?
Yeah, I think that he is in our side.
The disc jockey, he was making fun.
He was quoting Biden, in a way, by saying clean darky.
He is on our side as black people.
He thought it was a wrong thing to say.
It was a joke.
I hope we're not going to misread him as saying Barack Obama is a clean darky.
That's not what he meant.
We have to attend the context, don't we?
Well, we don't need to pay attention to it at all.
The question is what - sorry, go ahead, E.R.

I was saying we don't really have to pay attention to it at all, but this points out that wit the rising star of Barack Obama we're getting everything from left, right, up, down that he is having to deal with.
Is he black enough, is what some black people have asked.
Is he too black, which is what some white conservatives have asked?
Did he diss his minister by not allowing him to come to his announcement ceremony?
Does he have slaves in his background, his family being owners of slaves.
Everything is coming out reminding us that race is so close to the top level of our lifestyles in this country, and through Obama we're being forced to think about it.
So if you think you're telling a joke, you've got to be aware that it's not going to necessarily fly because we haven't quite got there yet…
Yeah, that's…
That we can laugh about this stuff.
That really goes back to what John was saying, because he was saying, look, this was imbedded in a joke but the DJ got suspended.
Jeff, do you think that that was a good decision?
No, I don't.
I think in this particular - see, I'm the first one that's going to jump on somebody for saying something wrong.
We can go at it.
But I think that question is intent.
Was he saying it at a tongue-in-cheek, and it sounds like he was casting aspersion on Biden more than Obama.

The other thing is we get peeved off about words, and in this case, darky, that he used tongue-in-cheek while other words like discrimination, hatred, oppression, economic inequity and many other big beautiful words get acted out every single day in the society.
We don't get peeved off enough to attack them in mentality or institution.
So I think the NAACP is barking up the wrong tree in this particular case.
So I think they should reprioritize.
Well, the NAACP doesn't even know where it's going these days.
Their leader said he is sick of them himself and stepped down on Sunday, it was formally announced.
So we can't just look to the NAACP.
We've got to think about what are the priorities here.
And more and more of these kind of stupid things are going to be said and acted upon because Obama is running and he is black, and because Hillary Clinton is running and she is a woman.
All right.
We're going to leave it there.
And I'm sure we're going to come back to these topics again and again over the coming months.
E.R.
Shipp, professor in journalism at Hofstra University School of Communication.
She was joining us by telephone in this naughty, naughty weather.
John McWhorter, Manhattan Institute senior fellow in public policy at our New York bureau; Jeff Obafemi-Carr, host of the radio show ""Freestyle"" at Nashville, Tennessee's Spotland Productions.
Thank you all.
Thank you.
Thank you, Farai.

This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Rachel Martin.
The news is by nature a grim kind of business.
There's a lot of heavy stuff out there and some weeks more than others.
And no, puzzling cannot change the world.
But it can provide a few minutes of welcome distraction from the headlines.
Joining me now is Will Shortz.
He's the puzzle editor for The New York times and WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle master.
Good morning, Will.
Good morning, Rachel.

Yeah.

And you were in the middle of a table tennis tournament.

It went real well.

My team and I played so well we were bumped up into a higher category.
And then the second and third days we got smashed.

But we had a great time.

You can't be, like, a genius at everything, Will.

But you try.

Remind us of last week's challenge.
Yes, it came from listener Ed Pegg Jr. And it involved the name of the French film director Bertrand Tavernier, which is B-E-R-T-R-A-N-D and T-A-V-E-R-N-I-E-R.
And I asked what amazing word play property is in this name.
Well, it conceals the names of the ""Sesame Street"" characters Bert and Ernie, all three words reading left to right.
Bert and Ernie.

She joins us on the line.

Congratulations.

I just saw it in there.

I do.
